title: 1346-G
statement: G. Two IP Camerastime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou have two IP cameras of the same model. Each camera can take photos starting from some moment of time with a fixed period. You can freely choose the starting moment but you can choose the period only as one of $$$k$$$ values $$$p_1, p_2, \\dots, p_k$$$ which are chosen by the camera's manufacturer.You have $$$n$$$ moments of interest $$$x_1, x_2, \\dots, x_n$$$. You'd like to configure both cameras in such a way that at least one camera will take a photo in each of these moments. Configuring the camera means setting the moment when it takes the first photo and the gap between two consecutive photos (which should be one of the values $$$p_1, p_2, \\dots, p_k$$$). It's not a problem for you that cameras can take photos at other moments of time — you only care about moments of interest.InputThe first line contains two integers $$$k$$$ and $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le k \\le 10^5$$$; $$$2 \\le n \\le 10^5$$$) — the number of periods to choose and the number of moments of interest.The second line contains $$$k$$$ integers $$$p_1, p_2, \\dots, p_k$$$ ($$$1 \\le p_1 < p_2 < \\dots < p_k \\le 10^6$$$) — the periods to choose in the ascending order.The third line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$x_1, x_2, \\dots, x_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le x_1 < x_2 < \\dots < x_n \\le 10^6$$$) — the moments of interest in the ascending order.OutputPrintYES(case insensitive) in the first line if there is a way to configure cameras.In the second line, print two integers $$$s_1$$$ and $$$cp_1$$$ ($$$1 \\le s_1 \\le 10^6$$$; $$$1 \\le cp_1 \\le 10^6$$$; $$$cp_1 \\in \\{p_1, \\dots, p_k\\}$$$) — the starting moment and the period for the first camera. The period should be one of the given periods.In the third line, print two integers $$$s_2$$$ and $$$cp_2$$$ ($$$1 \\le s_2 \\le 10^6$$$; $$$1 \\le cp_2 \\le 10^6$$$; $$$cp_2 \\in \\{p_1, \\dots, p_k\\}$$$) — the starting moment and the period for the second camera. The period should be one of the given periods.If there is no way to configure cameras, printNO(case insensitive). If there are multiple ways, you may print any of them.ExamplesInput3 5 3 5 7 1 4 5 7 12OutputYES 1 3 5 7Input3 2 1 2 3 1 10OutputYES 1 1 10 1Input3 4 1 2 3 5 7 9 11OutputYES 5 1 5 1Input3 4 10 20 100 2 3 4 7OutputNO

processed.result:
You have two cameras that can take photos at regular intervals. You can choose the starting time for each camera and the interval between photos.  There are $k$ possible intervals to choose from: $p_1$, $p_2$, ..., $p_k$.

You have $n$ important moments in time: $x_1$, $x_2$, ..., $x_n$.  

Your goal is to configure the two cameras so that at least one camera takes a photo at each of these important moments.

**Input:**

* The first line contains two integers, $k$ and $n$ ($1 \le k \le 10^5$; $2 \le n \le 10^5$), representing the number of possible intervals and the number of important moments.
* The second line contains $k$ integers, $p_1$, $p_2$, ..., $p_k$ ($1 \le p_1 < p_2 < ... < p_k \le 10^6$), representing the possible intervals.
* The third line contains $n$ integers, $x_1$, $x_2$, ..., $x_n$ ($1 \le x_1 < x_2 < ... < x_n \le 10^6$), representing the important moments.

**Output:**

* If it's possible to configure the cameras, print "YES" followed by:
    * The starting time and interval for the first camera ($s_1$ and $cp_1$).
    * The starting time and interval for the second camera ($s_2$ and $cp_2$).
* If it's not possible to configure the cameras, print "NO".

You have two cameras that can take pictures at regular intervals. You need to set the starting time and interval for each camera so that at least one camera takes a picture at each of a given set of times.  Can you do this? If so, show how to set up each camera.
